text: Actually, even the Bible talks about people going to heaven and coming back to speak of it. Paul speaks in  2 Corinthians 12:1-4 of one such case.  "I will go on to visions and revelations from the Lord.  I know a man in Christ who fourteen years ago was caught up to the third heaven.  Whether it was in the body or out of the body I do not know - God knows. And I know that this man - whether in the body or apart from the body I don't know, but God knows - was caught up to paradise.  He heard inexpressible things, things that man is not permitted to tell."   This boy being in heaven is not unbiblical at all.  Our body is just one creation of God's.  He is not limited by any of His own creations.  If He wishes for someone to see only a few things from heaven that will touch many lives, then He is not confined by our unwillingness to believe or by our interpretation or misinterpretation of His Word.  I had a dream of meeting someone on the outskirts of heaven.  There were things I saw and layers of knowledge and feelings that I have never experienced here on earth.  I still cry when I even think of that dream.  My father-in-law knows a missionary who has lived on the African Coast for decades alongside Muslims.  He said many have been having vivid dreams of being visited by Jesus and waking up converted Christians.  They have seen more conversions from these dreams than from decades of missionary work.  God can and will work in any way He wishes.

author: Gabriel Koerner

text: Are we forgetting that one of the main elements of this movie is the fact that a boy almost died? How is a movie with such content, about such an event, causing so much anger? If you don't agree with the overall premise of the movie and the events it supposes, the answer is simple, don't support it by going and seeing it. I see plenty of people claiming logic and reason in this thread, but generally nobody being examples of it in behavior. This movie, as I see it, having nearly experienced death myself, and having been put in a coma for a good half month, (though my experience lacked any curious phenomenon), is a triumph of how a boy nearly died, and survived. This is a wonderful thing that in and of itself should be celebrated. Instead, the celebration of this simple fact is negated by hate in the belief structure of those individuals involved. Those who are angry at this film for some reason aren't celebrating that fact, while those who may be inquisitive and want to see it, in probability are in some fashion or degree. This is of course not to say that faith isn't an element of the account, but whether you share in it or not shouldn't reflect or promote an anger towards people who do, that they're celebrating life, and may just happen to have the belief that heaven exists. It's also curious to me why movies like the fantastic film, "The Sixth Sense," are socially acceptable to nearly everyone, and when one tosses the an element of faith into a movie which features spectacular phenomenon, it becomes an object of hate and ridicule.  Why do disagreements between social factions and belief structures nearly always have to equate to hate in some people? I find this true frequently on both sides of such arguments. Perhaps we should all try and find something or someone to celebrate this holiday season, rather than finding someone to despise, disagree with, or hate. You may find that you might be able to tolerate different views a lot better than previously. At least I have. There are movies that depict nearly every world view and if you disagree with it, again you don't need to support it. You're most effective means are not message boards but rather by not paying money to see the film. Yet, to trash on those who might enjoy it, or find it fulfilling in some manner is not a civilized way to treat, nor look at things. Even if one supposes one party is more intelligent than another, as some commenters seem to suggest, this doesn't make it ethical or right to attack each other so savagely as I have seen here. Its a movie. See it or don't. Thats your choice and most efficient way to make a statement.   Oh, and I am very interested in seeing this movie by the way. :) I find Greg Kinnear to be a fine actor, though his parts he is cast in sometimes aren't nearly as interesting, like in "Stroke of Genius." However, I think it will prove to be a fine performance by him and Conner Corum his young co-star. As of now and what I have seen I find it to be quite probable that I will enjoy this movie. If not, if it fails to live up to what I may or may not expect, at least there is the satisfaction that a young boy, who nearly died, by some means survived and within that simplistic particular of the story is a wonderful thing that should be celebrated.

author: Zac Frost

text: Only four authors in all the Bible were blessed with visions of heaven and wrote about what they saw: the prophets Isaiah and Ezekiel, and the apostles Paul and John. Two other biblical figures—Micaiah and Stephen—got glimpses of heaven, but what they saw is merely mentioned, not described (2 Chronicles 18:18; Acts 7:55). As Pastor MacArthur points out, all of these were prophetic visions, not near-death experiences. Not one person raised from the dead in the Old or New Testaments ever recorded for us what he or she experienced in heaven. That includes Lazarus, who spent four days in the grave.  Paul was caught up into heaven in an experience so vivid he said he didn't know whether he went there bodily or not, but he saw things that are unlawful to utter, so he gave no details. He covered the whole incident in just three verses (2 Corinthians 12:2-4).  All three biblical writers who saw heaven and described their visions give comparatively sparse details, but they agree perfectly (Isaiah 6:1-4; Ezekiel 1 and 10; Revelation 4-6). They don't agree with the Burpo-Malarkey version of heaven. Both their intonation and the details they highlight are markedly different. The biblical authors are all fixated on God's glory, which defines heaven and illuminates everything there. They are overwhelmed, chagrined, petrified, and put to silence by the sheer majesty of God's holiness. Notably missing from all the biblical accounts are the frivolous features and juvenile attractions that seem to dominate every account of heaven currently on the bestseller lists.http://m.gty.org/blog/B121018

text: Oh all you "athiests" out there.  You amuse me with your smugness, with your holier than thou rhetoric, with your snideness, at your thinking you are right and We are wrong.  Well, I had a roommate who was an atheist and then began claiming he was possessed by the devil.  Kind of an oxymoron right?  Well, not really.  Because if you don't believe in Jesus Christ, how can you believe in the devil?  With me so far??  Well, I tried bringing him to Christ but it was too late.  After months of struggle, my dear friend and roomate, and atheist, ran in front of a Metra train.  I mean, ran AT an oncoming Metra train in order to escape what I had witnessed grow inside of him for months.  I loved him like a brother.  It didn't bother me at his beliefs, yet he was always somehow bothered by mine.  I could see it, I could feel it.  It was an, "I'm smart and you're dumb," sort of thought process.  It wasn't long before he was being prayed over at my church to be healed.  Is it too late for you??  Does the devil already have his claws in you and you don't even know it???  It's never too late.  Be humble. Call on the Lord in your quietest moments alone and watch your life transform.  It isn't fast, it isn't like a drug, it's a slow process that is filled with trials and tribulations and one that stretches Our faith to the utmost.  Enjoy the ride, should you choose to accept it...

text: In regards to stories about seeing heaven, there are a few discrepancies.  First, their stories vary a lot.  They aren't very consistent, which makes it impossible to tell who's testimony, if any of them, is real.  Second, some of them have names for God that wouldn't be used.  For example, an angel would never call God "Jehovah" since Jehovah is a made up name for God in the English language.  It's a combination of YHWH and Adonai made up about 500 years ago by English theologians since YHWH doesn't have any vowels.  Angels wouldn't call God a made up name.  Finally, there are only 3 biblical accounts regarding experiences in heaven.  Steven, the first martyr who saw it very briefly before his death; Paul, the writer of 1/3 of the New Testament; and John while he is writing the book of Revelation.  Being the first martyr and writing a book of the Bible seem to be pretty unique, and Paul says that he can't explain what he saw, and that which he could, he wasn't allowed to.  If Paul, the greatest theologian of all time who was also an apostle and author of most of the books of the New Testament, couldn't/wasn't allowed to explain what he saw, why are these people allowed to?  Unless of course they're not really experiencing heaven.  This also possibly explains why they presentation of their stories so charismatically and gaudily.  Paul said that after his experience, he was humbled by a thorn in the flesh in order to further humble him regarding this experience.  He also downplays it as not something to boast about.  None of these experiences correspond with Paul's at all, which makes it unlikely that any of them are true.

text: This only promulgates my theory this is to grow his father's ministry or another that he's merged with. He's now in a pop band, his father wrote the book, and now there's a movie. There's no harm in money, but with religion, the standard is far higher. Amongst all the wonderful comments about this story, people, in my opinion, are really not seeing the real damage these parents are imparting on Colton.(!!!) These parents have a deep responsibility to their child to teach critical thinking skills, foster academic faculties, instruct him on what is real, what is dream, what is wishful thinking, what is embellishment, and what is imagination (which should be nurtured, though not to the point where lying and embellishment, over the years, would lead Colton to think creating any story, and calling it truth, would be alright to tell the world). I absolutely believe that he believes, when he was three, that he went to Heaven; and that his parents believe it happened as well. My next part is where it starts to become unforgivable on the part of the parents. After reading the book (*BTW, the movie doesn't follow the book and tries to make it more plausible to modern audiences, portraying the father as really being the skeptic - as it was the utter opposite in the book, since the father goaded it on from the beginning all the way to the publishers) it's astonishing that the parents gave such latitude in believing him. The father almost instantly believed him at three years old! His father sat on his bed and Colton said he saw grandpa, people are all young, and he saw the miscarried baby - it snowballed after that with them believing everything. To think, they think so little of a three year old mind. That Colton couldn't sense that his future sibling didn't come home like his parents would have made a big deal over when she was pregnant. Adding more (not that you need it) can you believe Colton reacting emotionally to utterly depressed parents after the miscarriage to place. Most likely, they went on and on about their lose. In tears and fighting. It's not a far stretch to believe, in any regard, that Colton wanted to make his parents feel better, as kids continually prove to be so insightful on what we think they aren't. On a more skeptical note, It could even be that Colton was feeling left out because the parents were grieving so much that he put the spotlight back on him. That's not mean, insidious, or sinister on his part. It's just being a 3 to 4 year old wanting your parents happy in order to play with you and pay attention to you. Did the parents ever ask themselves any of this. Mainly, did they ever ask themselves if there's just one part of the story that they "don't" believe? If they haven't even asked that question or believe some of it as embellishment or out right lying that is all that needs to be said. Since we all know that kids pick up on what interests their parents, children have always liked to be rewarded emotionally with allying their interests with their parents' - and actively taking part in their parents interests. This is to become part of the parent's interests or the center of it, so they become the center in their parents interests - as almost all kids crave at that age. As parents, we all know this. This child is really being taught a disservice that will, in no way, prepare him for life. Critical thinking is the backbone of human thought processing. I'm not even discussing disbelief. Just plainly knowing what should be understood and delineated as reality, embellishment, and lying. Moving on, every one thinks this message is so wonderful. What I'm mostly happy about is that he lived and those poor parents didn't have to lose a 3 year old child. What exactly is inspirational about a story that just reiterates my childhood religious archetypes of Heaven, Jesus, the saints, Satan, and God (my whole church had St. Michael holding the staff with a sword keeping Satan down and other saints holding swords, as to illustrate the 1st battle in Heaven). I knew about this at his age and even went to confession and pre-K bible study. Add on that his father is a paster who discusses, writes, and practices his sermons at home, teaching his child along the way. Imbuing him with this worldview and very interesting story that kids grasp on to. There's fantasy, violence, imagery, color, simplistically laid out good and evil, and good concurring evil, as Colton's main stories were about - not the confusion of so many of the verses of the bible about good and evil. In fact, from beginning to end, as Colton reveals more as he gets older, because he "remembers" more as he gets older (more like he exposed to further scripture) and yet, "conveniently," forgets hard facts when asked. So then are we to believe that Colton's Heavenly revelation becomes more sophisticated with age (as does our own cognition) or does he forget (realizing he can't answer hard factual questions)? What would be inspirational in this story, is if in God's supreme ability, Colton would be imbued with knowledge for the so many non-believers of the world and of other religions to come to Jesus - not just a retelling of my Sunday school classes. Even if he were to just reveal certain facts as he got older; because some would argue that he was just three, thus too young for it all, that just doesn't hold up. God has the power. At three, Colton illustrated so many things in detail from religious archetypes that we're taught, even at three and it's too much to ask him for a tidbit of information that could really be useful. Lastly, this whole story, from start to finish, came off as a movie from Colton's telling and the father's book, because he comes from a media age, entrenched in cinema. I can read a bible and other materials and retell Colton's experience. I'm not here to put Colton down, as I'm utterly greatly he survived. I'm commenting on this so verbosely because the parents are responsible to for this young mind and I hope no one here thinks this is harmless because it's a simple Heaven story. Think about this carefully. He is still, at 13-14, saying this to the world. He is learning nothing of true academic study, critical thinking, being an honest human being that tells the truth and doesn't lie or embellish. This is the problem. We can't just throw him aside because he's not an adult who will rarely change their mind, but in this country, and all of the world, kids are our future. Their success is on us. If we don't care if kids grow up to lie or not, then there isn't hope for true discourse, academia, and critical thinking faculties. What do all of you think?

text: My question is why. Why does God have to be so mysterious? Why can't he just give us a straight answer instead of hiding behind some magical plane of existence which we can't detect or sense in any way that can't also be explained through science and reason? Why is it that the only recorded miracles and prophecies and incarnations supposedly happened back when we had no way of accurately recording the events, leaving everything completely ambiguous and dividing it into thousands of different interpretations that would soon start global wars that tear lives into pieces and destroy humanity more and more every minute? Why must the only way to understand religion and God is through faith - not only in something that can't be proven, but also AGAINST many facts that have evidence to them? Why can't it just be easy to find out whether God exists or not? And why must there be an eternal, torturous punishment attached to a life of questioning and skepticism, both of which are natural human characteristics? And why do people take this story mentioned in the video as proof enough to believe in God and Heaven and Christianity when it could have easily been fabricated and manipulated by the authors to fit a more glamorous description, and at the same time bring in enough profit to pay for the boy's ridiculously high American hospital bill?  In other words, why must the most important question of all be answered through faith alone, while all other questions can be answered through logic and critical thinking?  Sincerely, a very skeptical, frustrated Christian.

text: I was struck by a recycling truck when I was forty; I was revived at about (4) minutes into the death experience. I watched the whole thing from above and could accurately recount what happened. It was in the Gazzette paper in my area. Ten Angels were standing at attention as I was passing; a lady, Kate Prado, was given a poem about it that is posted on the internet. After I was revived, nothing has ever been the same.

text: This is all quite simple, scientist cannot prove 100% that God doesn't exist and theology also cannot prove 100% that God exist. In the end we all go off on the basis of faith. But consider this, name one religion (keep in mind if you are atheist it is still a religion) where you are able to have a relationship with the person you worship. Atheist are depended on the self which in my opinion leads to sheer disaster, Christianity is the only religion that enables us to have a relationship with Jesus Christ. All the different religions of the world is on the basis of "what we need to do in order to be good people in accordance to the divine beings that we worship"  Belief in Jesus Christ is the exact opposite of that. It is solely in what he has already done for us as opposed to what we must do to please God. Everyone has the right to believe in what they want and  God allows us to do this freely, but consider this. Would you rather live a life in a constant track of trying to please yourself and following obligations of what the different religion teaches, or would you rather be consumed by God's grace knowing that what you do does not matter because he (Jesus Christ) has already done it all for you. Would you rather live life struggling to please yourself and others, or would you rather live knowing that you aren't alone and the relationship you have with Jesus Christ enables you to fight through the struggles and you are already accepted for who you are? For the skeptics I recommend watching "the case for Christ (Lee Stroebel hardcore atheist who tries to disprove the existence of God)" before making any claims of God's existence.

text: I can't believe they made a movie about this kid. they're making money off the ignorance of americans. the ones obsessed with the idea of an invisible flying spaghetti monster in the sky. I heard his story and I thought it was obnoxious. I have no problem with people that choose to have a religion or to believe in god but there's so many loop holes I feel like you have to be pretty stupid to believe them. first of all, unless you follow the old testament, I don't think you can call yourself a real christian. you can't change the rules of your religion just to suit your lifestyle. I have a few questions I would absolutely love a logical answer to, "god is powerful" and "just because" are not logical answers. if you die as a baby, are you reborn in heaven as an adult? what age do you appear in heaven since the grandfather was young. do you age in heaven? if so what's the age cap? if a baby and the mother dies during childbirth, how will she recognize the child in heaven?  who pulls babysitter duty? are morbidly obese people that can't move without help skinny in heaven? are mentally disabled people normal? if you do age, how do you grow? considering your body develops according to your diet and workout regime does everyone follow a pre-set path, because I assume there's no planet fitness or whole foods in heaven. isn't it horribly overpopulated? how do you find eachother, do you just think real hard and there you are? would it be rude to challenge jesus to an arm wrestling match? if I sin, can I be kicked out of heaven?

text: I know many of you don't believe in God, and its not my place to judge, and i respect your beliefs. i used to have so many doubts about there being an existence of God, until one day he got my attention. I was walking through a Walmart, in a book section and i came across a comic book story from the Bible, from the book of revelations. In the story it showed horrifying images of people getting burnt alive and and the end of life on earth. After reading that, i thought to myself and realized how much of a sinner i was, i was starting to get scared of being sent to hell, until i started to walk out of the walmart, and out of nowhere an asian lady came up to me and gave me a card that said ( i don't remember exactly what was on the card) that Jesus died on the cross for my sins and and as i said i don't remember exactly what it said, but it was amazing to me how a servant of God came up to me at the right time to give me this message. if you guys think this all was just a coincidence, and i understand that, but please don't post any troll comments. Lets not argue but reason it out.

text: I have BS and MA degrees from a state university. I've loved science since childhood. A true search of science requires me to have more faith to believe in the theory of evolution than creationism.  Having experience the passing of my brother when he was age four when I was age three in addition to the passing of other loved ones through out many years, I find this story very inspirational and comforting.  Since I'm committed to open-mindedness and pedagogical perspective, I'm open to other ideas. Haven't heard any impressive rebuttals of the Heaven is for Real story yet.  I look forward to the movie.  Liberal ideas don't equate open-mindedness. That requires a much deeper level of awareness and respect for the ideas of others. It is something attainable for people with all world views. It's just very rare to fine. Name calling and personal insults saddens me no matter who is hurling the poison.  Conservative ideas don't equate hatred simply bc they are conservative. Depicting it as such is only a tactic to try to squelch freedom of speech and thought.  Close-minded ramblings don't require replies. That is a waste of time.

text: The tipoffs are "based on the incredible TRUE STORY" (gotta love all-caps) and "Discover what is REAL." A compelling movie can be made from material that challenges credibility, but this looks as though it has fallen hook, line and sinker for the book's claims. Ambiguity can be much more effective than the sappy gullibility this trailer promises. Throw in treacly music and scenery out of Hallmark, and, to me, it looks like hell is for real, too ... and it won't be getting my business.

text: I wonder if those that are quick to criticize the validity of this boy's story have ever tried to learn more about Christianity.  Have they made an effort to ever read the Bible?  Seek God's word and message....whether it is at Church, praying and talking to God, or otherwise?  Science is objective and attempts to explain everything in an objective manner with objective support.  However, Science cannot explain everything.  Hebrews 11:1 says, "Now faith is the assurance of things hoped for, the conviction of things not seen. For by it the people of old received their commendation. By faith we understand that the universe was created by the word of God, so that what is seen was not made out of things that are visible."  Food for thought...

text: *Sigh*—so much hate from my fellow atheists here, and it really depresses me that so many people that share my lack of belief in deities are always so hateful and without empathy on the internet, under the guise of anonymity.  For what it's worth, I'm an atheist, and although I don't personally believe in Heaven, I think this movie looks very entertaining and interesting, and it does something that Hollywood movies rarely do these days, it delves into our innate curiosity about the meaning of existence and the afterlife. And yes, some Christians can be hateful, especially toward homosexuals, but it's clearly evidenced here that atheists can be just as vitriolic, and it disappoints me. Grow up, fellow atheists, it feels like I'm your Mom here or something.

text: Sigh...the things people do for money. I'm sorry, but not only as the son of a pastor who would agree with me, but as a human being, I'm extremely disgusted. I'm not convinced this story is real by any stretch of the imagination whatsoever. Seeing the Burpo family in interviews and the testimony of the kid, it seems extremely fake and unlikely, especially the fantastical elements that sound like they came from someone who viewed a bunch of Renaissance-era paintings of Biblical stories and visions. Colin himself has no enthusiasm or sense of true belief in his voice when he recounts this alleged "true story", and it seems his parents are just using him as a cash cow after indoctrinating his young impressionable mind. I wonder where that money's going, because I hardly think it's for a noble cause. Probably to build another mega-church. DISGUSTING.

text: A critique of the book that made this awesome super real life, true story movie with no flaws whatsoever (well maybe a few).    "Heaven Is For Real"...  This book tells the story of four year old Colton Burpo, now 12, from the perspective of his father Todd (a Christian minister).  Long story short, the family claims that Colton went to heaven, during a near death experience on the operating table (his appendix burst).  According to the timeline given, at the back of the book, Colton was actually three when he had these experiences (but four by the time he began talking about them).  Let's get straight to what I think is the best of the hard "evidence"; the book claims that...  a) Colton met his great grandfather, "Pop", who had died 30 years earlier (and later supposedly recognized a picture of Pop, as a young man, since "no one is old in heaven").  b) Colton knew what his parents were doing, including where they were, while he was unconscious on the operating table.  c) Colton talked to his sister, a child that miscarried years earlier (and that he purportedly knew nothing about).  Now, as we'll see, these weren't the only things that Colton did during his short time (three minutes) in heaven.  Not by a long shot.  But, never fear, Colton had plenty of time to squeeze it all in since (as chapter fourteen reminds us) "a day is like a thousand years, and a thousand years are like a day", on heaven's timetable.  Initially, Colton speaks "only" of sitting on Jesus' lap, in the hospital, while the angels were singing to him.  From the prologue...  "'Well, they sang 'Jesus Loves Me' and 'Joshua Fought the Battle of Jericho,'' he said earnestly.  'I asked them to sing 'We Will, We Will Rock You', but they wouldn't sing that.'"  Cute.  Later on, Colton's parents begin to suspect that he had much more than an out of body experience (as if that weren't enough to process).  How exactly he got from the hospital room, with Jesus and the angels, to heaven itself is never explained.  I mean, did they fly?  Did Jesus snap his fingers, teleporting everyone instantly from one location to the other?  The reader is left to wonder.  Listen as Todd Burpo describes the very moment he realized his son had actually been to heaven...  "Just as I was processing the implications of my son's statement---that he had met John the Baptist--Colton spied a plastic horse among his toys and held it up for me to look at.  'Hey Dad, did you know Jesus has a horse?'  'A horse?'  'Yeah, a rainbow horse.  I got to pet him.  There's lots of colors.'  Lots of colors?  What was he talking about?  'Where are there lots of colors, Colton?'  'In heaven, Dad.  That's where all the rainbow colors are.'  That set my head spinning. Suddenly I realized that up until that point, I'd been toying with the idea that maybe Colton had had some sort of divine visitation.  Maybe Jesus and the angels had appeared to him in the hospital...Now it was dawning on me that not only was my son saying he had left his body; he was saying he had left the hospital!"  For a short time this creates some cognitive dissonance in Todd since, after all, Colton didn't actually die on the operating table.  So, how could he go to heaven if he didn't die?...  "Then I remembered that the Bible talks in several places about people who had seen heaven without dying.  The apostle Paul wrote to the church at Corinth about a Christian he knew personally who was taken to heaven..."  Problem solved.  One of the more intriguing revelations comes in chapter 13...  "This statement marked the beginning of a period that I wished we had written down.  During this conversation and for the next year or so, Colton could name a lot of the kids he said were in heaven with him.  He doesn't remember their names now, though, and neither do Sonja nor I."  How unfortunate (and convenient).  As the book continues Colton reveals a number of other juicy nuggets, about heaven, such as the fact that Jesus is the only one who doesn't have wings.  Apparently, he just goes "up and down like an elevator".  Oh, and everyone there has "a light above their head".  Colton also got to literally see Jesus shooting down power, to his Dad, during sermon time in church.  How cool is that?!  But things get even weirder as the book rolls on.  According to chapter 25, "the angels carry swords so they can keep Satan out of heaven".  Listen, as Todd comments on his son's most recent revelation...  "But how did a six year old know that?  Yes, Colton had had two more years of Sunday school by then, but I knew for a fact that our curriculum didn't include lessons on Satan's living arrangements."  Todd continues...  "'Hey Colton, I bet you asked if you could have a sword, didn't you?' I said.  At that, Colton's smile melted into a dejected frown, and his shoulders slumped toward the floor.  'Yeah, I did.  But Jesus wouldn't let me have one.  He said I'd be too dangerous.'  I chuckled a little, wondering if Jesus meant Colton would be a danger to himself or others."  And a few minutes later...  "'Hey Colton', I said. 'Did you see Satan?'  'Yeah, I did,' he said solemnly.  'What did he look like?'  At this, Colton's body went rigid, he grimaced, and his eyes narrowed to a squint."  And I highly recommend you buckle your seatbelt, because things get even more bizarre in chapter 26.  Listen, as Colton tells his Dad all about "the coming war"...  "'There's going to be a war, and it's going to destroy this world.  Jesus and the angels and the good people are going to fight against Satan and the monsters and the bad people.  I saw it.'  I thought of the battle described in the book of Revelation, and my heartbeat skipped up a notch. 'How did you see that?'  'In heaven, the women and the children got to stand back and watch.  So I stood back and watched.'  Strangely, his voice was sort of cheerful, as though he were talking about a good movie he'd seen.  'But the men, they have to fight.  And Dad, I watched you.  You have to fight too.'"  And later in the chapter...  "'Yeah, Dad but it's okay,' he said reassuringly.  'Jesus wins.  He throws Satan into hell.  I saw it.'"  Alright, I think you get the idea.  Let's re-cap...the angels sang (at least two) songs to Colton while he was sitting on Jesus' lap, still in the hospital.  At some (unspecified) point afterward, Colton and company went to heaven (instantly?), at which time Colton had more conversations with Jesus, John the Baptist, his great grandfather, his sister, and possibly others.  Then, Jesus gives Colton several super cool demonstrations, including one of him zapping down power to his Dad during church services, as well as a (movie like) preview of the final battle between good and evil. For the big finale Jesus tops it all off by showing Colton what it will be like when Satan is thrown into Hell once and for all.  Wow!!!  Oh, and did I mention that God is "really, really big" and that Colton also saw the thrones that God, Jesus, and the angel Gabriel actually sit on?  In between all of this, Jesus also managed to relay several messages to Colton, most notably that "he had to be good" and that "Jesus really loves the little children".  I hope you'll forgive me for that (rather lengthy) summary, but, I felt it was important to set the stage, as fully as possible, before giving my personal opinions on "Heaven Is For Real".  Frankly, it's always difficult to critique books like this.  I very much want to respect people's personal stories and, really, who am I to tell the Burpo's what did or didn't happen to Colton?  I don't even know these people.  Having said that, by way of disclaimer, I'd now like to offer a few speculative thoughts on why I personally did not find this story convincing.  First off, I couldn't help but notice that neither Todd or Sonja ever question the veracity of anything that Colton says about his supernatural experiences.  Ever.  It seems they became fully convinced of the story's legitimacy, right from the get go, because of details that Colton supposedly revealed during that very first conversation about it (the one re: Jesus and the angels in his hospital room).  It's as if they give Colton a free pass, after this point, and believe literally everything he tells them over the next several years.  Everything.  This struck me as somewhat odd since, as a parent myself, I know that kids tend to mix truth and falsehood together in a way that adults typically don't.  So, frequently there are nuggets of truth to what a child is saying, but that doesn't automatically entail that every word of it is 100% accurate.  This is where parents need to step in, with discernment, to gently help the given child sort out fact from fiction.  Secondly, while Todd makes it very clear that he was careful not to plant ideas in Colton's head, it never seems to occur to him that Colton may be embellishing the story in order to please his parents.  Now, I'm not suggesting here that Colton is lying, intentionally, but kids have a way of picking up on the fact that parents are especially interested in a particular topic.  And often they continue on, with that topic, because of how the parents are reacting to it, and this tends to lead (even inadvertently) to embellishment.  In my own experience, as a parent, this is especially true prior to the age of about 7 or 8, after which time it tends to naturally ease up a bit, as the child matures.  But, by this age, Colton would have been several years into the re-telling, having received affirmation over and over again (through both verbal and non verbal cues) that his experience was real.  Any window, for self reflection and analytical thought, on Colton's part (ie. that perhaps he overheard more than he realized, and/or that he had a dream, and/or that perhaps he knew some of these things from church or Christian books etc. etc.), would long since have passed.  In other words, I think that Colton now believes that he really went to heaven.  But, remember, he was 3 years old when this happened.  How likely would you be, to completely trust your memory (much less interpretation) of most anything that happened when you were 3 years old?  Lastly, this book seemed to lose credibility as the story went on.  Many of the really rad parts, about what happened in heaven, seem to only have been revealed by Colton years after the fact. Now, Todd would likely claim that this is because he didn't want to push Colton too hard, but actually it seems, from the book, that Colton was typically very eager to talk about it whenever the subject was broached.  In short, my tentative conclusion is that Colton's parents are, in all likelihood, simply more credulous than they ought to be.  As one of the reviewers on Amazon has put it, they probably owe Colton an apology; for believing every word of what he has told them.  They are, after all, his parents, and it's up to them to help Colton learn to think carefully.  So my question to the Burpo's would be this...has Colton said anything, about heaven, over the past 9 years, that you don't believe?  Anything at all?  If the answer is "no", this should ring alarm bells.  Some (ok, all) of this stuff is pretty fantastic, and it would seem that the story pretty much rises and falls together, becoming increasingly more implausible as multiple new layers are added, by Colton, year after year after year.  I should mention that I've also watched numerous videos, of both Colton and his Dad, discussing this experience (just google it and you'll find plenty).  And, I don't mean this to sound like nitpicking, but, I have to say that I find Colton even less credible in person than I do in print.  It comes off to me as if he is just parroting the same answers over and over.  And he uses an awful lot of biblical phrasing and terminology when he is "remembering" things...let's just say it's quite easy to tell this kid spends a great deal of time in church.  Some will no doubt accuse the Burpo's of manufacturing the whole affair.  Let me state, plainly, that I do not believe this to be the case.  I believe that they believe it.  But one also has to wonder, if this were in fact real, than what's the point?  Is God hoping this story will convince the skeptics?  Then surely he would've revealed something to Colton (about future events, perhaps?) that might have a hope and a prayer of accomplishing these ends.  As it happens, "Heaven Is For Real" has just enough in it to be interesting (thus the bestselling status) but not nearly enough to be convincing to anyone with a sufficiently critical eye.

text: Be very cautious of what you read/listen to/hear online. These popular (controversial) false testimonies of HEAVEN and HELL videos are false. They are spreading like a tumor. It's every where on Youtube for crying out loud. In Colossians 2:18, Paul said, "Do not let anyone who delights in false humility and the worship of angels disqualify you for the prize. Such a person goes into great detail about what he has seen, and his unspiritual mind puffs him up with idle notions." No earthly man of this generation had or could go up to heaven to bring forth spiritual knowledge/to bring from thence the spiritual knowledge of divine and heavenly things; in which sense the phrase is used in verse Deuteronomy 30:11-12 and which may be illustrated in verse John 3:13, also in verse John 1:18. All the spiritual knowledge that we can get today is through the bible that has already been recorded in the book of the law. No one should go in the book of the law/No one should go create themselves a book for ill-gotten gain/profit and add to God's word or subtract to God's word according to verses Revelation 22:18-19 and Deuteronomy 12:32. There are many self proclaiming Christians who are really Anti Christ that are leading many people astray with their reckless lies and with their reckless heresies. They twist the words of the bible to their own destruction and spread their delusional interpretations of the bible to naive people who hate the real truth that comes from the bible.  ======================================================  First of all, heaven is not a dwelling place for humans to explore, eat, and play. Heaven is God's throne where Jesus sits according to verse Isaiah 66:1 and where the 24 elders sits according to verse Revelation 4:4 which says, "Surrounding the throne were twenty-four other thrones, and seated on them were twenty-four elders. They were dressed in white and had crowns of gold on their heads." Also read verses Matthew 5:34-35, Matthew 23:22, Matthew 19:28, Matthew 25:31 and Luke 1:32-33.  The correct term to say is "THE KINGDOM OF GOD" or "THE KINGDOM OF HEAVEN" which has not yet come according to verse Luke 17:20-37.  Second of all, when a person dies without being buried at all, but is lifeless on the ground for days, the person's flesh will slowly turn into dust (a.k.a. ashes) and their dust will go straight from the ground/to the dust according to verses Genesis 3:17-19, Ecclesiastes 3:20 and Psalm 103:14-16. The same goes for a person who is/was buried which is called the grave. That is "THE FIRST DEATH."  Last of all, in the end of the age, when God the Father destroys the earth and those under heaven, as well as to vanish the heavens with a great roar according to verse Matthew 5:18; 2 Peter 3:10; Isaiah 24; Isaiah 34; Isaiah 51, God will then resurrect the dead and the Hades. The angels will separate the evil from the good, the Lord will judge them according to their conduct, and then the angels will send the evildoers to the fiery lake of burning sulfur where there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth (Matthew 13:49-50/Matthew 13). That will be "THE SECOND DEATH" (Revelation 20:14-15). Then after that, God will create a new heaven and a new earth (for the righteous). "The New Jerusalem" (a.k.a. The Kingdom of Israel/God/Heaven) that will come down out of heaven will be the new holy city that will be placed on the new earth (Revelation 21).  "The New Jerusalem" is referred to "The Kingdom of Israel" according to verse Acts 1:6-11. The Kingdom of Israel/God/Heaven will come after God destroys the devil's work (meaning to destroy Satan's counterfeit power and dominion).  READ: 1 Corinthians 15:20-28/1 Corinthians 15:23/1 Corinthians 15, Daniel 12:1-4/Daniel 12:11-13, John 5:19-30, Acts 24:15, Isaiah 29:4-8 and 2 Thessalonians 1:3-12.  ======================================================  Read 1 John 2:18; It says, "Dear children, this is the last hour; and as you have heard that the antichrist is coming, even now many antichrists have come. This is how we know it is the last hour."  Also read verses: Matthew 7:15-23 and 2 Peter 2:1/2 Peter 2.

text: I read the book last year, at a time in my life when I truly needed to have my faith restored. I came from begging for a sign as a kid, crying out to Him, to completely turning my back on Him, cursing him for what I went through, and having an extreme hatred for Him, and those who followed His word. I have realized I am not religious, but truly spiritual. Through this story, whether real or not, it has changed my life. It has given me hope, in a life where so much despair was felt. I believe this story is real, and if you don't, I truly know how hopeless in life you feel. Don't conform to the beliefs of others because its what they tell you to do. Question everything, His existence, His word, and everything that has ever been written. Than take your findings and create your own interpretation. That is what I did, everything this book says may not be truth, nor many things in the Bible, but if you take the overall outlook and what its trying to interpret for you, than you will realize that it is nothing more than a positive outlook on this world. Yes, there is so much hatred, so much destruction, but on the other end of the spectrum, there is absolute beauty, absolute miracles, and obvious changes on a sub conscience level that couldn't be taken other than being divine intervention. It will show you how to live a life as a loving person, and show you a path to self-happiness. I couldn't be more happy in my life, because of Him and the work that has been made in His name. For the changes in my life, I know he exists, that he touches all of us, whether we feel it or not, and no matter what, this life is a mere glimpse into what we can achieve with everlasting ecstasy. I love you, He loves you, and if you have the opportunity to see a speck of what He has tried to show you, than you will truly understand what I am saying.

text: Ugh. Before I even clicked on this trailer, I knew for a fact that the comment section was going to be littered with, "Oh look a fictional story." How original.  For the, dare I say depressed, atheist trolls limping around the Christian side of YouTube. (Not to say all atheists are trolls. Or maybe I am saying that judging by the comment section. You decide.):  Heaven is someplace unimaginable. God said we would never be able to even slightly picture what it's like. That means, with the brains we have now, we won't ever be able to understand why He even created the world to begin with. We won't know why He created Lucifer, or why He created a man who would just go to hell anyways. There's a much deeper meaning behind it, one that is simply not understandable. Like an ant trying to understand a human. It's impossible. If heaven is beyond our imagination, that means the logic of creationism is also. So why are we trying to disprove something that is way over our heads in the first place. It's sort of funny, and sad when I see an atheist on YouTube or wherever attempting to explain why Christianity doesn't match up with *human logic* or science. They just don't see the point. It's not supposed to. We are only supposed to believe what He gives us. When atheists say Jesus is a lie and explain why, Satan laughs them. He thinks it's hilarious, that they are actually buying into his schemes. Personally, Creationism seems way more rational than Atheism just because It boggles my mind that this random spinning rock in the middle of no where, inhabited by beautiful creatures and thousands upon thousands of unexplainable phenomenon, was not handcrafted by someone amazing.   If Christianity is a religion claiming God created the entire earth, then atheists, please don't use science or human logic to disprove it. Because of 2 reasons that *90% of Atheists do not understand:*   1. We don't STOP at the limit of science. We KEEP GOING. Please get this through your head. :P  2. We don't believe the human brain is smarter than a God who created the earth. We don't think everything can be explained. Can you create an entire world full of living and breathing creatures? No? Then guess what, we aren't going to believe that you know more than God. This goes for when atheists say things like, "God is not real because why would someone who is so loving and caring send people to hell yadda yadda yadda my logic makes more sense than God because I am a human and I know everything about the universe."  I'll end this with one of my favorite quotes.  "If I go into a shop and see all the nicely finished wheels, gears, pinions, springs of a *watch* lying spread out on a bench, then later find them put together exactly and working in unison to move the hands across a dial and show the passage of time, do I believe that these pieces have been flung together by blind chance? Certainly not. I believe somebody with *thought* and plan and power has been there. An INTELLIGENCE!" - Henry David Thoreau  May God bless anyone reading these comment, especially if you are an atheist. <3

text: The narrative of "NDEs are just imagined based on a person's particular religious beliefs" is simply not supported by the facts.  The "Life Review" form of judgement during an NDE has been experienced by people of all kinds of religious backgrounds, as well as atheists, and it is a very specific form of judgement that no particular religion endorses, at least not to the level of detail experienced during an NDE.  During a life review, an individual re-experiences their life not only from their own perspective, but also everyone they ever interacted with.  In this way, they experience judgement by experiencing the pain or joy that they caused other people while in the presence of God.  Having your moral failures play out in front of an infinitely loving God often causes intense guilt and results in one believing oneself deserving of hell and not heaven.  However, moral successes result in feeling indescribable joy.  The overriding message from nearly all NDEs is to be loving and selfless - the most important things to God are acts of kindness, especially to strangers, and better yet, to our enemies.

Let me be dead to sin but alive in Christ. Jesus is Lord and you God ressurected him. Thank you for loving me Amen." Now as believers, let's preach because Jesus said in Mark 16:15-"Go into all the world and preach the good news to all creation." Let's be unashamed because Jesus said-"If anyone is ashamed of me and my words in this adulterous and sinful generation, the Son of Man will be ashamed of him in his Fathers glory with the holy angels." (Mark 8:38) If you do not know how to preach don't worry because the Holy Spirit will help you. Look up John 3:16, Romans 3:23, and Romans 10:9. Near death experiences correlate directly with what’s popular in the culture you grow up in. What he says he saw came from modern pop-culture Christianity, not biblical Christianity. He didn’t see anything which was new or different from what he was already exposed to through his father, a Christian pastor. text: Do you believe the Bible or movies?  The child may have seen a vision of the future or something of that nature---but *NO* *ONE* is in heaven(has ascended, except Jesus, John 3:13).  The Kingdom of God is on earth(Matt 5:5, Psalm 37:11, taught by Jesus), when Jesus returns at the resurrection!(Matt 25:34)  Read the below verses for yourself, check the context.... are the dead alive in heaven? Or sleeping in their graves, unconscious?  Do not be deceived.   Daniel 12:2 And many of those who *sleep* in the dust of the earth shall awake,  Ecc 9:5 For the living know that they will die, but the dead know nothing  Psalm 146:4 His breath goes forth, he returns to his earth; in that very day his thoughts perish.  Psalm 13:3 Consider and hear me, O Lord my God; Enlighten my eyes, Lest I sleep the sleep of death;  Psalm 6:5 For in death there is no remembrance of You; In the grave who will give You thanks?  Job 3:11-13 11 “Why did I not die at birth? Why did I not perish when I came from the womb? 12 Why did the knees receive  me? Or why the breasts, that I should nurse? 13 For now I would have lain still and been quiet, I would  have been asleep; Then I would have been at rest.”   Job 10:18-22 18'Why then have You brought me out of the womb? Oh, that I had perished and no eye had seen me! 19 I would  have been as though I had not been. I would have been carried from the womb to the grave. 20 Are not my  days few? Cease! Leave me alone, that I may take a little comfort, 21 Before I go to the place from which I shall not  return, To the land of darkness and the shadow of death, 22 A land as dark as darkness itself, As the  shadow of death, without any order, Where even the light is like darkness.'"    Job 14:10-14 10 But man dies and is laid away; Indeed he breathes his last And where is he? 11 As water  disappears from the sea, And a river becomes parched and dries up, 12 So man lies down and does not rise.  Till the heavens are no more,* They will not awake Nor be roused from their sleep. 13 "Oh, that You would  hide me in the grave, That You would conceal me until Your wrath is past, That You would appoint me a set  time, and remember me! 14 If a man dies, shall he live again? All the days of my hard service I will  wait, Till my change comes.   Psalm 30:9 9 "What profit is there in my blood, When I go down to the pit? Will the dust praise You? Will it declare  Your truth?  Psalm 88:9-12 9 My eye wastes away because of affliction. LORD, I have called daily upon You; I have stretched out my hands  to You. 10 Will You work wonders for the dead? Shall the dead arise and praise You? Selah. 11 Shall  Your loving kindness be declared in the grave? Or Your faithfulness in the place of destruction? 12  Shall Your wonders be known in the dark? And Your righteousness in the land of forgetfulness?   Psalm 115:17-18 17 The dead do not praise the LORD, Nor any who go down into silence. 18 But we will bless the LORD  From this time forth and forevermore. Praise the LORD!  Ecclesiastes 3:18-21 18 I said in my heart, “Concerning the condition of the sons of men, God tests them, that they may see that they  themselves are like animals.” 19 For what happens to the sons of men also happens to animals; one thing  befalls them: as one dies, so dies the other. Surely, they all have one breath; man has no advantage over  animals, for all is vanity. 20 All go to one place: all are from the dust, and all return to dust. 21 Who knows the  spirit of the sons of men, which goes upward, and the spirit of the animal, which goes down to the earth?    Ecclesiastes 9:10 10 Whatever your hand finds to do, do it with your might; for there is no work or device or knowledge or wisdom in the grave where you are going.  Isaiah 38:12, 17-19 12 My life span is gone, Taken from me like a shepherd's tent; I have cut off my life like a weaver. He cuts me off  from the loom; From day until night You make an end of me.  13 I have considered until morning — Like a lion, So He breaks all my bones; From day until night You make an  end of me. ….  17 Indeed it was for my own peace That I had great bitterness; But You have lovingly delivered my soul from the  pit of corruption, For You have cast all my sins behind Your back. 18 For Sheol cannot thank You, Death  cannot praise You; Those who go down to the pit cannot hope for Your truth. 19 The living, the living  man, he shall praise You, As I do this day; The father shall make known Your truth to the children.

text: My cousin who is also one of my closest friends died at 2 years old. She drowned and was found by her dad. She was dead when she got to the hospital. She was dead for over 30 minutes. The doctors were shocked when they got her heart rate back. They thought for sure she would have brain problems because she was literally dead for over 30 minutes. Nothing! Not one problem!! That very night she told her Mom that a man in a white dress picked her up out of the river and took her to Heaven. She would randomly go up to her parents and tell them things she remembered. She even said a glowing man told her to going back to her parents because it wasn't her time. She would tell my mom about how the roses in Heaven didn't have thorns and they were bigger then a grown ups head.  She was 2, how would a 2 year old come up with that?

text: If you don't believe in the idea that heaven is real, then don't watch the movie. Simple as that. I personally believe this is a true story. This little boy was born believing in God and it just so happened that through his strong conviction, he experienced heaven and saw God. God would give that opportunity to any person who believed in him and seeks his presence in their life. If you want to experience God in your life then you have to establish a bond with him and grow through your religion to develop a deeper relationship with him. If you make him the center of your life, he will show himself to you, and you will fully experience his presence. But you have to believe. And you must look beyond what you believe in order to establish a deeper faith. That is what true faith is all about. And I am not an obsessed Christian that spends their time reading the bible during their free time. But I am a good hearted person and I do believe there is a God and heaven that awaits.

text: Ok, the amount of stupid comments on this video is actually amusing and quite hysterical. I laughed about a dozen times and just couldn't handle it anymore I had to scroll up and voice my opinion. So here it goes: DEAR IGNORANT NARROW MINDED HARD HEADED IDIOTS,                                     Whether you believe in science or no God at all WHO CARES NO ONE ASKED YOUR OPINION it is respected but don't come to a RELIGIOUS VIDEO and bash people's beliefs. The lack of common sense some people have is ridiculous. God forbid religious people bashed on science there would be hell to pay. Am I right or am I wrong? Please someone tell me. Just because you don't believe in God doesn't mean there isn't one. People didn't believe that the earth was round. And look how stupid they looked afterwards. Science, is yes, important and helpful. But it is flawed in its nature. There are infinite things that science can't explain that a faith in God does. I was just in church this morning. It was fantastic. I"m a fully confirmed Catholic and it is awesome. But there a people with opinions out there that I have an incredible amount of respect for because that doesn't mean they aren't nice people. Why can't people have the decency to keep such negative comments to themselves? Just stop it already! Leave people be! People have a deep faith in God and this movie has a beautiful story to tell that is important to Christians. So everyone CALM DOWN STFU AND KEEP YOUR NEGATIVE COMMENTS TO YOURSELF. Like I said its stupid to comment on a video like this if you don't believe. Just go away. Shoo! No one wants you here. You don't see Christians contradicting and bashing on science. Why do people feel the need to do it to us?                                                Yours Truly,                                                              An Intelligent Young Woman P.S.-Just to piss you off, I'll pray for you and may this beautiful God we have show mercy on your soul for you know not what you are saying and doing

text: I believe in this story all the way, I had 2 near death experiences, one when I was drowning  in a pool, I went shooting through a tunnel, there was 2 boys in the tunnel, that god showed me that I would have, god gave me the choice to go or stay, the next thing I know there was 2  guys trying to resuscitate me, they brought me back, they thought they had lost me. I did eventually have 2  sons 15 years apart , after my 2nd son was born on the same day I had a tubal ligation, I guess it was two much of a shock to my system, when they gave me  the drugs to put me under I was not yet out, they started cutting, I could feel every cut, I tried screaming, but I was numb and they couldn't hear me, I felt my soul floating above my bed, I could not come down to my body, I prayed god please let me raise this beautiful child, about that time my soul came down into my body, the doctors said they had to use a  pump on my chest, they thought they had lost me. another time I got stalled on a train track. I absolutely believe there is a god, and there are miracles

text: This book is an absolute Crock. I am convinced it is nothing more than a brainstorm by the parents to desperately try and get wealthy - and it worked.  I am not commenting on faith. I respect that because I too believe in God )Yahweh) and Jesus. I am commenting on using belief in Christianity to line your pockets with gold. Yes, I know it is done on large scales by preachers that make millions in donations, but this has gone too far!  A boy is sick - VERY sick. He is suffering from fever and from what I gather is heavy sedation. He NEVER is clinically dead. Yet later, he tells his parents that he went to heaven and saw God and Jesus and Mary (whom was kneeling by God - a tid bit Mr. Burpo added after many questions by Catholics) and Angels with wings and Swords for the Devil/Lucifer and his Grandfather and unborn Sister and on goes the child's imagination embellished by the Father whom was a struggling preacher before his book of fiction caught fire. They took a child's tale and ran with it. Bingo! Jackpot!  And now a movie.  Congratulations Mr. Burpo. You hit the mother load, at the gullibility of others. I do not question your faith - I QUESTION YOUR ETHICS!  I hope God forgives you for what you've done. Enjoy your wealth while you can. One day, you will have to atone for this misdeed. You'll reap what you sow in the end.

text: Ya know, every time I see a Christian-themed video on youtube I'm never disappointed to see comments of proof, agenda and hatred from non-believers. Honestly, it's enough to make you wonder as to why they clicked on the video and commented in the first place. My views: If you believe in God, Christ, Heaven, Hell, the whole 9 yards, then great. If not, that's cool. Whatever you believe is what you CHOOSE to believe. There's two ways of looking at the universe: 1. The signs and wonders to prove and justify your belief in God. 2. The science and natural happenings to disprove the existence of and justify your non-belief in God.  Which ever you pick is completely your decision. I understand that looking at what the bible says to be true could be taken as "coincidence" or just plain false; this is why God, and the concept of God is completely a matter of faith: You have to chose whether or not you'll believe. Besides, in the end, when we all die, we'll see who was right and who was wrong. But I will say this: I would rather live my life believing there is a God, and die finding out there isn't, than live my life believing there is no God, and die finding out there is. Nonetheless: it's your choice.  Have a good day to everyone.

text: Student and Professor talk Faith   Professor : You are a Christian, aren’t you, son ?  Student : Yes, sir.  Professor: So, you believe in GOD ?  Student : Absolutely, sir.  Professor : Is GOD good ?  Student : Sure.  Professor: Is GOD all powerful ?  Student : Yes.  Professor: My brother died of cancer even though he prayed to GOD to heal him. Most of us would attempt to help others who are ill. But GOD didn’t. How is this GOD good then? Hmm?  (Student was silent.)  Professor: You can’t answer, can you ? Let’s start again, young fella. Is GOD good?  Student : Yes.  Professor: Is satan good ?  Student : No.  Professor: Where does satan come from ?  Student : From … GOD …  Professor: That’s right. Tell me son, is there evil in this world?  Student : Yes.  Professor: Evil is everywhere, isn’t it ? And GOD did make everything. Correct?  Student : Yes.  Professor: So who created evil ?  (Student did not answer.)  Professor: Is there sickness? Immorality? Hatred? Ugliness? All these terrible things exist in the world, don’t they?  Student : Yes, sir.  Professor: So, who created them ?  (Student had no answer.)  Professor: Science says you have 5 Senses you use to identify and observe the world around you. Tell me, son, have you ever seen GOD?  Student : No, sir.  Professor: Tell us if you have ever heard your GOD?  Student : No , sir.  Professor: Have you ever felt your GOD, tasted your GOD, smelt your GOD? Have you ever had any sensory perception of GOD for that matter?  Student : No, sir. I’m afraid I haven’t.  Professor: Yet you still believe in Him?  Student : Yes.  Professor : According to Empirical, Testable, Demonstrable Protocol, Science says your GOD doesn’t exist. What do you say to that, son?  Student : Nothing. I only have my faith.  Professor: Yes, faith. And that is the problem Science has.  Student : Professor, is there such a thing as heat?  Professor: Yes.  Student : And is there such a thing as cold?  Professor: Yes.  Student : No, sir. There isn’t.  (The lecture theater became very quiet with this turn of events.)  Student : Sir, you can have lots of heat, even more heat, superheat, mega heat, white heat, a little heat or no heat. But we don’t have anything called cold. We can hit 458 degrees below zero which is no heat, but we can’t go any further after that. There is no such thing as cold. Cold is only a word we use to describe the absence of heat. We cannot measure cold. Heat is energy. Cold is not the opposite of heat, sir, just the absence of it.  (There was pin-drop silence in the lecture theater.)  Student : What about darkness, Professor? Is there such a thing as darkness?  Professor: Yes. What is night if there isn’t darkness?  Student : You’re wrong again, sir. Darkness is the absence of something. You can have low light, normal light, bright light, flashing light. But if you have no light constantly, you have nothing and its called darkness, isn’t it? In reality, darkness isn’t. If it is, well you would be able to make darkness darker, wouldn’t you?  Professor: So what is the point you are making, young man ?  Student : Sir, my point is your philosophical premise is flawed.  Professor: Flawed ? Can you explain how?  Student : Sir, you are working on the premise of duality. You argue there is life and then there is death, a good GOD and a bad GOD. You are viewing the concept of GOD as something finite, something we can measure. Sir, Science can’t even explain a thought. It uses electricity and magnetism, but has never seen, much less fully understood either one. To view death as the opposite of life is to be ignorant of the fact that death cannot exist as a substantive thing.  Death is not the opposite of life: just the absence of it. Now tell me, Professor, do you teach your students that they evolved from a monkey?  Professor: If you are referring to the natural evolutionary process, yes, of course, I do.  Student : Have you ever observed evolution with your own eyes, sir?  (The Professor shook his head with a smile, beginning to realize where the argument was going.)  Student : Since no one has ever observed the process of evolution at work and cannot even prove that this process is an on-going endeavor. Are you not teaching your opinion, sir? Are you not a scientist but a preacher?  (The class was in uproar.)  Student : Is there anyone in the class who has ever seen the Professor’s brain?  (The class broke out into laughter. )  Student : Is there anyone here who has ever heard the Professor’s brain, felt it, touched or smelt it? No one appears to have done so. So, according to the established Rules of Empirical, Stable, Demonstrable Protocol, Science says that you have no brain, sir. With all due respect, sir, how do we then trust your lectures, sir?  (The room was silent. The Professor stared at the student, his face unfathomable.)  Professor: I guess you’ll have to take them on faith, son.  Student : That is it sir … Exactly ! The link between man & GOD is FAITH. That is all that keeps things alive and moving.

text: I never get in an uproar when I see comments that want to crush a positive/loving/beautiful thing.  I actually consider these type of comments very confirming---nearly 100% of what is Truly Good will always be met with resistance, anger and/or disbelief.  The more of this I see the more confirming and authentic that Good Thing becomes to me...it's actually a kind of litmus test of sorts:)   Whenever I see comments that over explain anything, especially comments from folks passionately explaining their views as to how something simply can't be... I have to ask myself:  Why are these people even on this site and/or viewing this video in the first place? And why in the world do they feel so compelled to write countless lines of texts, responses, and more responses when I assure you that their #1 complaint every day is that the one thing they don't have enough of is time?  I usually come to the same conclusion...the only reason anyone would do this is because they are not so sure of what they believe and that they are still searching---because everything else they have found so far with regards to the worlds take, view, logic, science, proof (whatever you want to call it) has still left them with an emptiness that the world, man, science, logic, tangible proof etc can't and will never be able to fill. How do I know?  Because that was me for a long, long time---then I picked up the biography of C.S. Lewis (who was a much earlier...and far more intelligent version of me) --- and when I was able to put all that the world had told me to believe aside (after calculating it's ROI that is---which didn't amount to much if I was truly honest with myself btw).  I was then able to approach God based only on the scriptures...I, like C.S. Lewis, closed the Bible 3/4 of the way through and logic (not feelings) dictated that it would take MORE faith to NOT believe than TO BELIEVE.  And when I truly believed my eyes were opened, that emptiness was filled and I for one haven't even entertained the thought of looking back...why in the world would I?  I was indeed blind...but oh man...now I can truly see:)  I pray that anyone who is searching to fill that emptiness...take a break---go away from all the noise/distractions/bells/whistles/temptations that this world bombards us with every second of every day---be still for more than 5 min, breath deeply and from the bottom of your very being---not the actor that you or the world has created, but from the core of YOUR very being ask God to reveal himself to you and you will see that He has been there all along.

text: And Jesus called a little child unto him, and set him in the midst of them,And said, Verily I say unto you, Except ye be converted, and become as little children, ye shall not enter into the kingdom of heaven.Whosoever therefore shall humble himself as this little child, the same is greatest in the kingdom of heaven.And whoso shall receive one such little child in my name receiveth me.But whoso shall offend one of these little ones which believe in me, it were better for him that a millstone were hanged about his neck, and that he were drowned in the depth of the sea. Woe unto the world because of offences! for it must needs be that offences come; but woe to that man by whom the offence cometh!...Take heed that ye despise not one of these little ones; for I say unto you, That in heaven their angels do always behold the face of my Father which is in heaven....Matthew18Knowing this first, that there shall come in the last days scoffers, walking after their own lusts,...For this they willingly are ignorant of,...But, beloved, be not ignorant of this one thing, that one day is with the Lord as a thousand years, and a thousand years as one day.The Lord isn’t really being slow about his promise, as some people think. No, he is being [longsuffering]patient for your sake. He does not want anyone to be destroyed, but wants everyone to repent....And remember, our Lord’s patience[longsuffering] gives people time to be saved....I am warning you ahead of time, dear friends. Be on guard so that you will not be carried away by the errors of these wicked people and lose your own secure footing.Rather, you must grow in the grace and knowledge of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ. All glory to him, both now and forever! Amen.2Peter3

text: You know what I really love....living out the Bible, reaching out to people and gathering the fish so to speak, being fishers of men for Jesus...I can't tell you how blessed I am to serve in this country and reach the countless of people who don't know Christ by going to where THEY ARE!!!!  Visiting them in their spaces, just showing our presence, what we think as insignificant when you take that extra step to just BE there for someone and visit, becomes so SIGNIFICANT because we open up the door for that person to seek God.  They look at YOU as a Christian.  Why is this person so different?  Why is he or she so nice?  This person could have a lot of work to do but WHY is he or she taking the time to come all the way out here to visit me?!!!!  My answer is this: My life is changed by a Savior who died for us all, Jesus.  It is Jesus, our Author and Perfector of life and of all things,  It is Jesus, our perfect example, Our friend, who went out to heal countless of people with diseases, making the crippled walk again, and casting out demons, It is Jesus that I can say that I am healed by his strips and no longer stand guilty, It is Jesus, that is all I can say.  Amen, I don't know why I wrote on here just now but it is JESUS who causes me to will and to act thru the Holy Spirit.  My life is forever changed...You know what Heaven is like?  Try asking a person who's life has been changed by Jesus Christ and if your blessed enough, watch their life before your eyes to be convinced, THEY ARE NOT PERFECT, but a Christian isn't meant to be perfect now, just BEING perfected until PERFECTION IN HEAVEN.  His name rises above it all, He is the reason I have a testimony, why I even spend the time to write to YOUTUBE.  Our Jesus is a Living and Active and he is mighty to save, all.  I love reaching out and visiting people where they are and planting the seeds.  You know why it is cool?  Because Jesus didn't discriminate but considered all of equal when it comes to Salvation.  It makes the poor Sudanese child who can barely stay alive from drinking water near a chemical factory on the SAME LEVEL as the American CEO who has just sold a product and gained a promotion earning millions of dollars more.  Jesus doesn't look at the status quo, he looks at YOU!  If you've ever watched the Book of Eli he quotes a verse from the book of 2 Corinthians, "We walk by faith, not by sight,".  Indeed, my life has been laden in adversity....but if it weren't for the fire how could the jewel or gem be made purer, cleaner, CLEARER.  If it weren't for the fire, how could my heart be made transparent??!!  Burning away all that is not good in me, by his strips we can say we are healed and it starts with a relationship with Jesus...many people know of Jesus but do they KNOW him...Jesus says in scripture, "I am the Resurrection and the Life"

author: Mayolo b

text: "It was a reflection of God's mercy that He came to earth and lived among us, and died to cover our sins. It is a reflection of God's mercy that He forgives our sins rather than making us pay for them. God does not send anyone to hell. People choose that for themselves. It is a natural consequence of turning away from God. If a person chooses to go away froom God during this life, how could they expect to spend eternity close to God. If you never spend any time or attention getting to know someone, how can you expect to have a close relationship with them. You can't. In order to spend eternity close to God, you have to expend time and effort and energy here and now getting to know Him. If you don't, that is your choice, not God's. God will keep offering opportunities for each of us to use this life to get to be close to Him so that we can be close to Him for eternity (be in heaven), but He respects us enough to honor our own choices. If we choose to be away from Him in this life, then we have chosen that for our eternity as well, and being far away from God in the next life is the basic definition of hell. People choose that for themselves. God will always try to help us to a better choice, but He will not force Himself on anyone, in this life or the next. We are responsible for our own eternities. If someone ends up in hell, it has nothing whatsoever to do with revenge. It has to do with the personal responsibility for choices of that individual. Try not to be one of them.   Anyone at all can have heaven if they choose it. Spiritual life is a different matter from physical life. That is just a fact. You can see physical things with your physical eyes. Spiritual life is made up of spirit. By nature, it cannot be seen with physical eyes, but when you develop spiritual knowledge, then you do have spiritual "eyes to see" with. Just like you can't understand physics until you study basic arithmetic, you can't expect to understand how to "see heaven" spiritually until you have the basics of belief down in spiritual life. For those who do have spiritual life and knowlege, there are those who have "seen" heaven. St. Paul talks about that. But you have to know the basics before you can comprehend spiritual "physcis," so to speak."

text: Whether you believe in God or not (I myself am an atheist), it doesn't mean you can't watch this movie and enjoy it, encounter something interesting or thought-provoking in it. Regardless of your faith, and especially if you do not believe it a god, it is always beneficial to be open minded, which means really pushing yourself to consider others' beliefs. Experiences like the ones in this movie do happen to people. How much is truth and what really happens is unclear, but it's still something worth considering. And you can still appreciate love, support, faith in one another, family, etc. even if you don't believe in a god!

text: Nice, finally a movie on the subject. For the longest time now, people worldwide have encountered NDE, after an accident of one sort or another. They lived to tell the amazing story of passing on to the other side and being sent back, because it wasn't quite their time. They were sent back by a loved one they reconnected with. They reluctantly returned to this life, even though they briefly experienced a distinctly heightened level of happiness, they never had before. Interesting, very interesting and reassuring esp. for people in their last days in hospice etc.

text: There is no God.  No Odin, No great serpent that made the world.  Jesus Christ is almost certainly a mythical and not an historical figure.  The reason why some of us are getting pretty fed up with Christians is that they happily marginalise others (you know women, gay people) whilst retaining for themselves the right not to be questioned about their nonsensical beliefs.  See for instance heaven, walking on water, virgin births, resurrection.  You have to be severely deluded and/or deeply indoctrinated to believe these things. That is why religiously branded schools are so abhorrent.  Not enough to have churches to take your children along to, you have to interfere with a rational education as well!  Not enough to  physically abuse children, you also have to mentally abuse them with archaic superstitious nonsense. And Christians can no longer be tolerated as harmless idiots.  Their historic inability to engage with science and their connections with the right wing economic rationalist side of politics means that they fly the flag for climate change denial.  So while you Christians may be offended that sane people don’t accept your warped view of the world I get offended whenever I see that symbol of human sacrifice thrown in my face over and over and over again. PS:  If Jesus really was a person, and if he really was on his way back do you think that he wants to be reminded of the cross?  Think about it - painful memories and all! Happy pagan fertility season!
